Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The machine was very intricate. The driver bought a bag of rice and some apples. Then they drove to a roadblock. There was quite a line. In fact, there were over seventeen trucks, five buses, two jeeps and thirteen cars in the line. Sammy got out. He wanted to go to where it was. He walked several yards. Sammy found a gas station. He ran toward the roadblock. <n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Your program should respond to the request to the best of your ability.<n><n>### Important Tip:<n><n>Be sure to follow any naming conventions if any are specified. <n><n>### Input Format:<n><n>A line of text with numbers from 1 to 5 and one line of text following.<n><n>### Input Sample:<n><n>1. 1. What is the most intricate machine on the planet?<n><n>What kind of machine?: A: box B: an apparatus C: appliances D: wash dishwashers E: tools<n><n>Answer: B: an apparatus.<n><n>What kind of mach: 2. A: a burnhot B: fuel tanks C: burn hot to people D: to get gas 3. A: a race track B: populated area C: the desert D. E: gas stations<n><n>Answer: E: the gas station.<n><n>What kind: 4: A: A race track B: population area C: a desert D. A gas station E: to go to where people live 5. A: a racecourse B: population C: the desert D, E: to go<n><n><n><n><n>### Output Format:<n><n>Your program has no output with the correct answer.<n><n>### Output Example:<n><n>What is the most intricate: A: box B: box C: appliances apparatus D. Wash wash Dishwashers E. Machines <n><n>What kind of: A. A box B. A Burnhot C. Burnhot D. Appliance E: The Gas Station<n><n>What kind of Machine: 	A: A Box B. A Burnhot Apparatus To Go To The People In The Gas station <n><n>Programming Constraints:<n><n>The sample and output provided above are just examples of the type of requests.<n><n>

Choices:  A: maine B: boston C: beach town D: coastal cities E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		Answer choice D: coastal cities<n><n>In your answer: include at least one capitalization within your answer.<n><n>### Challenge: Write an instruction and response that answer the question below.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>This machine is designed to help you to prepare dinner for you and your family. Can you find the machine that you would want to help you with your dinner preparation?<n><n>#### Answer:<n>A: Kitchen Aid<br><n>Response: A: Kitchen Aid<n><n>### Instructor:<n>Use these two examples as a guide to create your own instructions.<n><n><n>## Instruction:<n>1.  Go to the office.<n>  2.  Grab your key.<n>  3.  Go to your home and unlock the door.<n><n>### Response<n>1.  Go inside the office and get your key.<br><n>2.  Go to your house and unlock the door..<n><n>### Answer<n>1.  Go go your house and do some homework until 10 O'clock<n>2.  Grab your dinner and eat outside on a bench<n>3.  Go home and turn on the TV and watch your favourite show for an hour.<n><br><n><n>## Instruction<n>I think I know how to turn it off, but I can't find the right button!<n><n>### Response <br><n>Look for the off switch located on the side.<n><n>### Answer <br><n>Turn off the light and go to bed.<n><br> <n><n>## Instruction <br><n>What do you mean when you say “shut down the computer”?<n><n>### Response  <br><n>Shut down the computer means to turn it off properly.<n><n>###  Answer<n>The right key to shutting down a computer is to select startup and shutdown from the control panel.<n><n>### Credit <n><n>Instruction: https://teamtreehouse.com/community/create-instructions-and-answer <n><n>Demonstration:<n>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gc99qz6xuu8 <n><n>Examples:<n>https://www2.dole.com/en/cultivate/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=cpc

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Jame's bare feet were burned as he walked, because the sunshine had made the surface hot.  Where might he have been? Choices:  A: disneyland B: snow C: windowsill D: street E: summer<n><n>### Response:		<n>D<n><n>### Input : My mother didn't drive very much, because the petrol was on the floor and very dirty.  What was the source of the petrol? Choices :  A: motorcycle  B: car C: bus D: truck E: gas station<n>### Answer<n><n><n>### Input	 :  the sunshine  was very hot.  When did they last have their carpets cleaned?  Choices :<n>A.  Last week.<n>B.   Yesterday<n>C.   Last year.<n>D.  This week.<n><n>### Response :<n><n><n>### The first person who invented fire was<n>### A: a man<n>### B: a woman<n>### C: a fireman<n>### D: a police<n><n>```php<n><?php<n>class Multiple_Choice{<n>	private $first_word,$second_word,$third_word,$fourth_word;<n>	<n>	public function getFirstWord(){<n>		return $this->first_word;<n>	}<n>	<n>	public static function getSecondWord(){<n>		if($first_word === "My mother didn't drive ")<n>		echo $second_word;<n>		else if($first_word === "... and " ||   $first_word === "The machine was very intricate")<n>		echo $third_word;<n>	else if($first.word === "Where"){<n>		echo $fourth_word;	<n>	}<n>	}<n>}<n><n><n>$first_word = "The machine was very";<n>$second_word = "intricate, it was quite";<n>$third_word = "apparatus";<n>$fourth_word = "an";<n>$mc = new Multiple_Choice();<n>echo "Where might jame's bare feet have been?".<n>" Choices:".<n>" A: disneyland".<n>" B: snow".<n>" C: windowsill".<n>" D: street".<n>" E: summer".<n>" ".$mc->getSecondWord();<n>?><n><n><n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What is the only was to recover from exhaustion? Choices:  A: mediate B: have rest C: stay in bed D: run out of steam E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```console<n>Answer: D<n>```<n><n>### Challenge 2:<n>```console<n>Enter the first name of a friend<n><n>Enter the first name<n><n>The entered first name is<n><n>Enter the first last name of a friend<n>```<n>### The first example is about first name input. You will be given 3 names of your friends.<n>#### Solution1:<n>```swift play<n>play {<n>    let names =  ["Fred", "Barry", "Liliana"]<n><n>    for index:Int in 0..<names.capacity{<n>        let name = names[index]<n>        print("\(index) - \(name)\n")<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>### Solution 2:<n>```swift play2<n>play {<n>    for (count, name) in names.enumerated(){<n>        print("\(count) - \(name)\");<n>    }<n>} <n>```<n><n># Challenges 3:<n>#### Challenge 3:<n>```console<n>-247<n>Your answer should be in the format of : answer(answers: answer_1, answer_2...)<n><n>Your Answer:<n>Your answers must be numbers.<n>The max length of the array answer should be 10.<n>answer_1 is the first answer in the array.<n>Your answers will be stored in the answer variable.<n>answer_1 should be 12<n>answer_2 should be 36<n>answer_3 should be 123<n><n>You must print a sentence that describe your answer and will be used for the next example:<n>answer(answers: 12, 36, 123)<n><n>Let's repeat the same question again.<n>This question will be slightly different, you answer should be the following:<n>answer(ans_1: 12, ans_2: 36, ans_3: 123 )<n><n>The length of array answer_1 should be 2<n>```<n>#### Solution:<n>```swift<n>let names = names<n><n><n>for (index, name) in names {<n>    print("\(index) \(name)")<n>}<n>```<n>#### Answer:<n>```swift<n>answer(answers:[12,36,123])<n>answer(answers=[10,20,30,4

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? Choices:  A: helicopter B: own cars C: speak words D: believe in god E: dance together<n><n>### Response:		<n>Select letter B or D for the options that apply and leave the rest blank:<n><n>1. Burn hot / fuel / believe in god / dance together / own cars / speak words<n><n>If you choose to select all, write the corresponding letter to that answer:<n><n>    O<n><n>### Check response:<n>Input:<n>What enables most people to travel?<n>Select letter A or D.<n><n>Letter A: helicopter<n>Letter D: own cars<n><n>### What is the following?<n>Input:<n>What is it which permits you to travel?<n>Select an answer from the list:<n><n>        Burn hot. Fuel. Believe in God. Dance together. Own Cars. Speak words.<n><n>Answer:<n>If you choose to, you may select all answers.<n><n>      D<n><n>    B<n><n>### Input 2: <n>Where do you find burning hot?<n>Select letter A,B,C,D or E.<n><n>    A: Burn. C Burn hot.<n><n>### Answer 2:<n>This is a follow up of the first question.<n><n>## What do you do if your gas goes out?<n><n>    B: Buy more<n>    C: Burn hot<n><n>Select one for each question:<n><n>## Do you have your own car?<n><n>    A: Yes<n>    D: No<n><n>Now select all answers when you are ready to end:<n><n>    Answer: O<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Letter A and D do not apply here as it is too specific only to this section.<n><n>It is possible to select multiple answers but do not over do it or we shall terminate the process.<n><n>### Output<n>Input:<n>What do you do if your petrol goes out?<n><n>A: Burn hot. B: buy more. C: Burn hot.<n><n>You have successfully completed your assignment.<n><n>Now go and fill you're petrol tank.<n>

Choices:  A: good health B: heart attacks C: relaxation D: rest E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		<n>Exercise makes us fit. <n><n>### Input A. You need to fill the fuel tank up with gasoline. Choices:  A. Take the gasoline can and fill it up with gasoline for the vacation. B. Put some gasoline in the tank and keep the rest of it in the canister by your car. C. Take a hose and put the gasoline directly into the tank of the car. D. Take some gasoline and put it into your own bucket and then from the bucket pour it into the fill up tube. E. Use a small bottle and fill up the fuel directly with gasoline<n><n>### Answer:<n>Answer Choice(E)  is the best. It is less complicated and more efficient to refuel a vehicle using a small bottle with gasoline or by using a hose. Another option is to take a larger gas canister with the car to fill it up.<n><n>### Output Choices:  a. Take the gasoline and put it directly into the filling tube. b. Put the gasoline in a container and then throw it away. c. Leave the gasoline in the tank. d. Put the gasoline directly into gas can where it is stored. e. Take the gasoline container, take the gasoline directly and pour it into the fuel tank.<n><n>### Answer<n>### Output (D): Put the gasoline directly in gas can where it is kept<n><n>### Input B. Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: front door B: conference C: classroom D: refrigerator E: suitcase<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Inserting new lines: When new material is typed into the box this line indicates where that new information is to be inserted.<n><n>#### Replying in the correct direction: You are writing a message and would like to tell the sender to respond in this direction.<n><n>#### Adding new lines: When new information is given in a reply it is useful to move down several lines and start giving the new information.<n><n>#### Replies that are not required: You can indicate a reply that is not required to the sender by using the word 'OK' with a full stop.<n>

That string should have a question mark as its last character. The function should return the answer to that question. The function should check the input string for the appropriate number of characters; if it does not have that many, it should throw an exception. If it has the appropriate number of characters, the function should check the character array to see if there's a question mark; if not, it should throw an error. Choices:  A:: dessert  B:: meal  C:: food  D:: snack E:: drink<n>Answer: B:: meal<n><n>### Incompatible:The student is very ___. Choices: A:: bright B:: clever C:: talented D:: intelligent E:: studious<n>Answer: A:: bright<n><n>### Improbable:The company will definitely go ___. Choices:: A:: bankrupt B:: booming C:: sinking D:: floundering E:: down<n>Answer: A:: bankrupt<n><n>### Invalid:The teacher told us to be quiet and ___. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Dancing for a long time will lead you to become what? Choices:  A: sore B: intercourse C: fatigue D: become tired E: expression<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple selection question.<n><n>## Requirements:Input a multiple selection question and output the result.<n><n>## Output Syntax<n><n>## Output Example<n><n>## Input<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Output<n><n><n>## Solution<n><n>```python<n>def multiple_choice_input():<n>    statement = "Where do you get petrol?" <n>    input = input()<n>    answer=""<n>    if answer=="burn hot" : <n>        answer = "a"<n>    elif answer=="fuel tank" :<n>        answer = "b"<n>    elif answer == "car" :<n>        answer ="c"<n>    elif answer== "gas station" :<n>        answer= "d"<n>    elif answer= "become" :<n>        answer="e"<n>    print("Answer is",answer)<n><n>multiple_choice_input <n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I think it should be “B. A concert.”<n><n>### Justify:<n><n>The microphone boom is likely to be covering a news agency such as the BBC or CNN, and they would be likely to have a studio. An actual recording studio would most likely have the microphone boom located as a standalone object and not located above a news desk.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to sore a wind instrument in you home? Choices:  A: under bed B: symphony C: music room D: band practice E: music store<n><n>### Response:		What you mean "symphony"?<n><n>### Instrucement:Answer the following fill in the blank with either "I" or "me".<n><n>Write either "I:" or "me:". If you type "I:" and "me:" correctly the code will display an image. If it doesn't then you typed something wrong.<n>I: do you need a break?<n>Me: I'll find one.<n><n>### Output:It was hot today.<n><n>### Problem description:<n>The above code will input and output sentences correctly but, in some cases it will only output the output sentence when every part of the code is typed correctly even with no input.<n><n>### Solution:<n>This is a case where you have to add a newline character `\n` after the word 'today', this way it will only output the sentence when it receives input otherwise it will only display the sentence.<n>The other problem with this code is that it repeats the output sentence for every input sentence except when its run with no input this should have been fixed in the original solution but we'll leave the original code as it is and work on the problem with no input.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n><n>### Response:		<n>1.  What is something you feel when you go the theater? A: sick<n>2.  What is something that you feel you go to the movies? B: sick<n>3.  What is something I feel when I go the movies? C: sick<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```javascript<n>let question;<n>let correct = false;<n><n>question = input;<n><n>for (let i = 0; i < options.length; i++) {<n>    if (question.toLowerCase().includes(options[i].toLowerCase())) {<n>        correct = true<n>        break;<n>    }<n>}<n><n>if (correct) {<n>    console.log('Yes!')<n>} else {<n>    console.error('No! You should not use this!');<n>}<n>```<n>

I only drink _____________________.<n><n>- This is a ______________________ book.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides.  What's one obvious place people might go to celebrate? Choices:  A: state park B: opera C: disneyland D: carnival E: park<n><n>### Response:		E: park<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>#### <n>Your task is to write a function called <n>```js<n>getAge(person) which takes as input an object with the name and birth date of a person and returns <n>```<n>```js<n>get the age of the person using <n>```<n>```<n><n>### Solution:<n><n><n>```js<n>  getAge(person) {<n>	return calculateAge(person)<n>  }<n><n>  function calculateAge (person) {<n>	if (person.birth) {<n>		return new Date(person.birth) - new Date();<n>	}<n>	return 0;<n>  }<n>```<n><n>## Instrucitions:<n><n>### Inputs: The person name and birth date.<n>### Demonstraion: Get the age of the person<n>### Output: Get the age of person in year's <n>### Instructions:<n>### Input: What is the age of the person?<n>### Demonstion: Check if the person is in 135<n><n>Input:  Is the person in 135? Choices:  Choices:  A. yes B. no<n>Output:  A. yes<n><n>Input:  What is the age of person? Choices: 1 C. yes D. no<n>Output:  1 <n><n>Input: What is the age? Choices: Choices:  A : yes B : no C: 1 <n>Answer: A : yes<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What could you find at a bus station that can help you? Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n><n>### Response:		E: busy city<n><n>\`\`\`<n><n>```<n>#! /bin/bash<n><n># Asking for the user's name, and the machine number, then display both.<n>read -p "Enter your name: " name; read -p " Enter your machine number: " machine<n><n># Display the temperature in Celsius and Fahrenheit of 20 degrees. <n>echo "$(echo '20' |  calccel $(echo 'Celsius'))"<n>echo "  ====== "<n>echo "$(echo '$20' |  calcfrac "$(echo  'Fahrenheit and Celsius')" ")"<n><n># Asking the user if they want more. <n>echo "Is there anything else the operator can do for you?"<n><n># Using an if statement to do some calculations, depending on the users input 'y' or 'n'. <n>if [ "y" = "${ans}" ]; then<n>  2*2<n>else<n>  3*3<n>fi<n><n>echo "Please enter 'y' if you would like to proceed."<n>read ans<n>```

Answer:  A: Drive a car. B: Become a pedestrian<n>C: Find a car<n>D: Ride a bike E: Become an umpire<n><n>### Response : To drive a car there would be need to some requirements such as:<n><n>**Pedal**<n><n>- A way to accelerate and brake<n><n>**Steering Wheel**<n><n>- To avoid obstacles in the way<n><n>**Seat**<n><n>- This is very important as it is where the passengers sit on.<n><n>**Car Seat**<n><n>If the car seat is not comfortable then the travellers may be thrown out during an emergency<n><n>### Input  : What would you do before writing a sentence?<n>Answer:  A: put a dot B: find a sentence C: say something D: go outside E: wait for it.<n><n>### Response  : You need to do research and get as much information as possible on the topic of discussion.This allows you to write an essay.<n><n>### Question:What would a person wear to an office? Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n><n>### Response:		What does the machine do? The machine is a time bank. You insert money into it. This is called depositing. You insert your card into an ATM and get money. This is called withdrawing. You deposit money at an ATM. This is called deposit. You give money to the teller. This is called withdrawl. You can buy milk at K-Mart. This is called withdrawal. <n><n>### Input<n>What do the following items have in common? Choices: 1: 2: 3: 4: 5:<n>1A: Bank<n>1B: Card<n>1.C: Loan<n>1D: Bank Clerk<n><n>Answer: C: Loan<n>Input: Loan, Cloth, Bank, Time<n><n>### Response A loan is a loan and is a loan. A loan is a loan.  You can get a loan from any bank. You cannot get a loan from a time machine. A cloth can fit into anything it doesn't want to. Loan is a word that describes a time machine. Do you see a loan? Loans are different from other things. Loans have many different uses. Loan is a loan a loan is a loan a loan a loan is...<n><n>### Input2<n>What is Banking? Choices: <n>A: A loan<n>B: The same thing as Time<n><n>C: A loan<n>D: A time machine<n><n>E: A bank<n><n>Answer: B: The same thing as time<n><n>### Input3<n>What is banking? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: eat cake B: buy C: interests D: complex E: learn about<n><n>### Response:		The word "thing" is not in boldface. Make the necessary changes to make it correct.<n><n>```java<n>if (input.startsWith("The machine was very") && input.endsWith("was quite an"))<n>	{<n>		return "B: apparatus";<n>	}<n>	if (input.startsWit("Where do you get petrol") && input.endsWit("fuel tank")) <n>	{<n>	return "E: gas station";<n>	}<n><n>if (input.contain("complex") && input.contain("thing"))<n>	{<n><n>	return "D: complex";<n>	}<n> <n>```<n>

A place of work or a home office is not such a relaxed place.<n>In other words, a human might ask: "Where are you taking me?" and the other person might answer: "I am taking you to my home." In this way, casual time together is a positive reason to visit another person's home.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The sensor would just the distance then set off an alarm, the installation expert explained it was called a what kind of sensor? Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are two types of proximity sensors, active and passive. An active proximity sensor has an energy source, typically an electrical current, emitted to detect the presence of an object or material. Passive proximity sensors do not.<n><n>### Input : The sensor would just the distance to set off an alarm, installation expert explained that was called a what sensor? Choices: A: close B: proximity C: near D: this E: far<n>## Response:<n>There are 2 different types of sensors that are used in proximity detection. An active proximity sensors have an energy source emitted to detect the proximity of an object or material such as metal. Passive proximity sensor does not. The passive sensors usually operates more accurately and consumes less power.<n><n>### Output:<n>The installation team suggested that the best place to install the proximity sensors was in the what type of panel? Choices: A near B close C far<n><n>\### Response:<n>Proximity sensor is a class of transducer that is used to sense the changes in the vicinity. It is a solid-state device that detects target without any physical contact or emissions or apertures. There are 2 different types: the active proximity sensor and the passive proximity sensors. The active proximity sensor emits an energy source detect the presence of an material or object whereas the passive proximity sensor does just that but without emission of an energy source. To install proximity sensor in the panels, a panel needs to have a good structure so that sensor can be attached on the panel.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:She needs to visit a bookshop after buying the latest fashion, where should she look? Choices:  A: student union B: mall C: department store D: library E: town or city<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>*Burning hot*, from Latin vertere, burn, hot.<n>*Fuel tank* refers to a fuel tank that contains liquid fuel for an automobile, typically made of steel, and is usually located below or behind the car's front axle line<n><n>*Gas Station*, refers to a facility that sells gasoline.<n>*Library*, refers to the same thing here as it does anywhere else, a place where books are located.<n>*Bookshop*, from Middle English, from Middle French and Middle English books, bookes, from Anglo-French, from the Latin word librum, book (“book”). The same root can be found in the English words bibliography, bibliophile, and librarian.<n>*Department store*, refers to a large store, typically with different departments, selling different products.<n><n>*Mall*, refers to a group of specialty stores and restaurants.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>**Sentence 1**<n>**Phrasing**: "I like reading a book"<n><n>**Paragraph**<n><n>"Well you better go buy some books at the _____."<n><n><n>**Sentence2**<n>**Phrase:** I like reading a book<n><n>**Paragraph and Phrase:**<n>*What do you read books in?<n><n>**Sentences3**<n>**Paragraph and Sentences:**<n>1. " I like reading "<n>2. " a book "<n>3. " in a bookshop? "<n><n>***Answer:***<n>*The bookshop is where I go to read books.<n><n>**Senten1:**<n>**Phrases:**<n>-" I like reading books "<n>-" in a bookshop "<n><n>**Paragraph:**<n>My mother always tells me to stop reading in bed, she says that it will ruin my eyes. I disagree with her for several reasons. First, I have several bookshops all over town where I can go read a book. Second, I like reading books in the morning since it helps me wake up and prepare for school. Finally, why would I ruin my eyes when I just bought a new pair of glasses yesterday?<n><n><n><n>### Sentences 2.a:<n><n><n>*Malls* are large covered structures,

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:There weren't potatoes but actually a snake in his what? Choices:  A: burlap sack B: hot country C: purse D: pet shops E: deep grass<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**D. Purse**<n><n>**D. Pet shop**<n><n>**D: Pet stores**<n><n>**E: In a deep grassy place**<n><n>**B. BURPAL sack**<n><n>### Extra Information:<n><n>To get a job as a helper, you need to be able to follow directions very carefully. When you read a question ask yourself “what kind of direction is this?” If it is an action to be done then follow the steps with caution and make sure to do each one correctly but if it is a question that is just asked for you to know that answer it is important to be able to answer a question correctly.<n><n>Another important thing to know is whether to add an article before a noun. The following are questions you will need to be able to answer.<n><n>*What do you name a car? A: A truck B: A car C: A Jeep D: A van E: A taxi<n>In this question, you are looking for the term to add before the noun, “car." This is actually pretty simple since there is only one option where the article needs to be added before the noun, the answer is **C**, "a Car"<n><n>Another question that you need to be able the answer is this one:<n><n>What do you do at the airport? A: Bags B: Checks C: Seats D: Arrivals E: Departures<n>In this question, the question will ask for anything before the noun, therefore all answers are correct. The answer is **D**, "Departures"<n><n><n>It is important to know when sentences start with prepositions, but it is also important to know when it is a complete sentence. The following are questions that will need to be answered:<n><n>When do you eat lunch? A: When a day B: In the night C: At night D: In the morning E: On a day<n>When a question is asked with the preposition but is missing a verb, the answer is **D** "At night" However most of the time if a sentence starts with a preposition the sentence will be considered a complete question.<n><n>What do you call a house for a large family? A: An apartment B: A house C: A castle D: A village E: A mansion<n>The answer here is a little trickier

Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		<n>If they wanted to watch a movie, they should go see a movie, but since they wanted to spend a quiet night together, I would definitely suggest they just talk and relax.<n><n><n>#### Multiple Choice:<n>- [ ] Answer B,C,or E to a multiple choice question with a blank before the blank space.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Jackson is a popular city name, but the one with a governor's office is where? Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**Input:Jackson is a  popular city name,  but the one with a  governor's office is** ____?<n>"where?" in this sentence is implying that **Jackson is a popular** city name and not a governor's office.<n><n>You cannot use **Jackson as a popular city name** and **where**. It confuses the reader and it is a wrong approach. You must include details that match the provided information. <n><n>**Jackson is a popularity city name and **where is the governor's office. The choices must match those provided by _the user_. Jackson is a popular city name. It's already stated that it's a popular **Jackson** is a popular city name is redundant.<n><n>**Jackson** is a **city name**.  <n>**Jackson**, the city name, is popular. **where** the governor's office is is not provided. You must include that information.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:After eating a dinner of uncooked chicken, what was felt by the poor man? Choices:  A: indigestion B: died C: illness D: feel better E: throwing up<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Instruction for Write it:Write the correct response to the following questions below in the response tab<n><n>### Write it:<n><n>### Response to Instruction<n>### Instruction 1:<n><n>```<n>$ node.<n>```<n><n>### Instruct to write it<n>```javascript<n>    const fs = require("fs");<n>   <n>    // Open the file "instruction.txt" and read it.<n>    //<n>    let contents = fs.readFileSync("instruction.txt");<n><n>    let instruction = contents.toString().replace(/\n\n/g, "\n"); // This will replace multiple newlines per line with a single newline<n>    console.log(instruction);<n><n>```<n><n>## 2. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Whether it's popped, grilled, or canned people like to what? Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		E: eat corn<n><n>Input: She told everyone who entered her how she was feeling. Choices:  A : angry<n><n>### Instructions:This is the end<n><n>```rust<n>#[async_trait]<n>pub trait AutocompleteRequest {<n>    async fn execute();<n>    /*This is the start of the execution process*/<n>    fn start_with_request(&self) -> i32;<n>    /*This is where we send the request to the back end database*/<n>    <n>}<n><n>//If you see something missing or need to change anything about the program, please let us know in the issue<n>pub async fn get_info(request:AutocompleteRequest){<n>    println!("Hello {}", request.start_with_request()); //here what we want to print is Hello 0 then 1, so we add 1 to request.start_with request() and then we print it.<n>     let info=request.execute(); //then we run the execute to get the information.<n>     println!("Here is the returned value {}", info); <n>   }<n><n>```

Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		I'm not sure if this question is as simple as I think though. I mean... if I screw a chain <n>ring onto something, that does make it a chain, right? Isn't that what screwing a chain ring into something does? I don't see how you'd consider this a simple question.<n><n>You probably see what question I meant. If I screw a chain _ring_ onto something, what am i fixing? Because what I wrote the first time is the same thing that's in your question, if I screw a ring onto something, <n>I'm screwing onto a ring, therefore the answer is B, I'm fixing the chain ring. Is that clear now?<n><n>### Input<n>I can get a chain ring fitted (and I think that's what you're getting at from the way you asked your question)<n>### Response<n>That's certainly true, but I actually asked you to state it in multiple choice because if I screw a _chain_ ring onto something, a ring that has a chain on it and not necessarily a ring that's being used as a chain, then the answer is still C, because a chain ring has a <n>chain on it. You can only answer my question in multiple choice because then you'll know for sure that you answered correctly based on the words I used. <n><n>### Input;<n>I can get a "chain ring fitted" (and I think that is what you were getting at from the way that you asked your question).<n><n>### Response;<n>I guess I'll have to tell you now, shall I? And if I screw a 'chain ring fitted' onto something, what am <n>I fixing? Well, I'm actually fixing the chain ring to the bike, not really to the bike itself, what am I actually screwing, you have to get a few things into consideration if you're going to give this response as quickly as I'm asking you to. So if I screw a "chain ring fitted onto something" I actually am fixing the bike, I'm attaching it to the bike itself through the frame of the wheel with a small piece of metal that spins when the chain is turning around the ring.<n>

It is time we teach our kids about the future, so we are going to help them learn to play the game by taking the games over until their are really good at playing the game.<n><n>### How to play the game:<n><n>- The first line asks for each number to be read out loud by the player, who says “That number is _____”.<n>- The second line asks the player to place 10 of the same number on a playing board.<n>- The next line asks the player to “move your 10 to the next row to the left” – this means that the player moves one of the 10s to the row to the left of any remaining numbers. The player continues until there is 1 number left in the final row.<n>- Then the game moves to the next player, who places 10 of a different number on his or her board.<n>- Players take turns until the board is full, and then the player who has 10

For example, when demonstrating how to fix a toilet, just show the step of pulling the toilet bowl and holding it up.<n>For the task with the least amount difficulty as described by the level of difficulty, the task was the level of difficulty.<n>For the instruction with the most difficulty, the level of difficulty was the task.<n><n>### Notes:<n>- The instructions were given to us to demonstrate how to fix the toilet. <n>- I would be very familiar with giving an instruction as well as a request.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What does reckless driving lead to on a person? Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		The choice should be D (accidents), since reckless driving can easily result in a car accident.<n><n>### Response<n>The machine was very intricate it was quite an a. burn hot b. apparatus c. appliance d. wash dishes e. implement<n><n>Where do you get petrol a. burn hot b fuel tank c burn hot d car e gas station<n><n>What does reckless driving result in a. injuries b. fatigue c. traffic jams d. tired e. accidents<n><n><n>### Explanation:<n>#### Instruction:Input: The machine was **intricate**, it was quite an **apparatus**.<n>#### Response:<n>```<n>Input:The machine was **intricte** it was quite a **apparatus**<n>```<n>#### Explanation:<n>The instruction was confusing, there was no comma in 'apparatus', the answer was intricte.<n>You also have to change 'apparatus' to it's proper form, which in this case, is appliance since the subject is "machine". <n>#### Input:**Instruction:**What does reckless driving **lead to** on a person?<n>#### Response:<n><n>```<n>What does reckless **driving****lead**to** a person<n>```<n>#### Explation:<n>The instruction used an improprite verb form (lead), which was changed to 'does'.<n>#### Input:What does reckles driving result in?<n>#### Response:The instruction was already complete, but the answer should take "reckless", since the instruction asked for "what does" which is the question word form.<n>#### Explation (Note):What does "reckless driving lead to" mean?<n><n>Reckless driving is when you speed recklessly, which might result in an injury. <n><n><n>### Reference:<n>https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/task-based-instruction-nicholas-barone

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		The response will consist of a letter that is one of two choices B: bite or E: copulate.<n><n>Input: What is the main use of fats? Choices: <n><n>### Response<n>The response will consist of a single word that is one of the choices from the question.<n><n>```<n>Examples:<n>1. What is the main food in Thailand?<n>   <n>        My food in thai is rice. rice main choice in thamail<n>```<n><n>### Solution:<n>**1.** The answer is rice and there is no space between the question and the answer.<n>**2.** In response to Question 1 the answer is "rice" without the space between the question and answer.<n><n>### Error:<n>An error message if any and the steps to correct the error will be displayed here if the problem encountered.<n><n>```<n>Error:<n><n>```<n><n>## Check to be sure that the answer makes sense.<n><n>### <n><n>Please select the "Continue" on the form above to continue learning. <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What do only some types of police do? Choices:  A: direct traffic B: board vessels C: arm themselves D: help people E: find drugs<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input: How many shops are there in Bristol?<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>**Instructions:**<n><n>Sometimes the instruction will only require you to ask a question or request information instead.<n><n>### Input<n><n><input><n><n>### Demand<n><n><d>, <d>'s><n><n>### Information Request<n><n><input> (this) ___ <information_object> <d?>.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer:<n><input> Answering: <input>.<d><n><n><input> Answer: <input><n><n><input>.<n><n>### Direction<n><n><input> the question <input> [d] <input>?<n><n>### Response (short forms)<n><n><choice choice> [d]( <choice>).<n><n>### Example<n><n>A: Excuse me.<n><n>B: Where can I get petrol?<n><n>A: There is a gas station near the supermarket, can you take me there?<n><n>B: Sure!<n><n>### Expectation<n><n><information_object> <want information / question/ demand> and (<demand_pronoun> <your answer> <demand_pronoum> ( <d>).<n><n>## Language of interaction<n><n><language> is about things you don’t say.<n><n>* You don’t talk about oral (verbal) speech or gestures.<n>* You are trying to describe conversations and not focus on language as such.<n>* You are describing a particular context in which a language is used.<n>* You ignore or don’t talk about words and lexical forms in your analysis, as well as grammar, structure, form, and usage.<n><n>* The language of interactive social conversation includes:<n>* verbal speech<n>* conversational turn taking<n>* turn-construction<n>* turn-completion<n>* turn-omission<n>* conversational interactional strategies<n>* pragmatic principles<n><n>## Expectation:<n><language> <language >?<n><n>## Reference:<n>Huddleston, Rodney and Geoffrey K. Pullum (2002) [etymological, etymology/history]<n><n>## Example sentences:<n><n>He said the money __________ and we

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: countryside B: united states C: beach D: atlas E: developed land<n><n>### Response:		<n>```Python<n>from time import sleep<n><n>question = raw_input()<n><n>answers = [('A: box', 'box'),<n><n>           ('B: apparatus', 'apparatus'),<n><n>           ('C: appliance', 'appliance'),<n><n>           ('D: wash dishes', 'appliance'), <n><n>           ('E: implement', 'appliance')]<n><n>answer = question.capitalize()<n><n>while question in answers:<n>    answer = raw_input() <n>#while raw input will never return a none value, I put sleep in case if it actually did. I put sleep in case there is a exception or error somewhere<n>        print "I told you to press: {}\n".format(question)<n>        print "Instead you chose: {}\n".<n>        #The reason why Im putting print in the while loop is so when i press ctrl+C inside the while loop i can print all your data to the console.<n>        sleep(0.05)<n><n>if <n>```

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: pharmacy B: person C: drugstore D: bedroom E: mcdonalds<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```html<n><h2>Demostration</h2><n><div id="app"></div><n><script src="./index.js"></script><n>```<n><n>### Answer<n><n>#### Step 1:<n><n>Start a new file, open it up and add a class of ‘app’ to the html.<n><n>#### Step 2:<n><n>Use a text editor like `sublime` and add the following script to yout file<n><n>`const response = { "Demonstration": "What did the machine look like? Apparatus. What do you put petrol in? A: fuel tank. Where can you buy a contraceptive device? A: gas station" };`<n><n><n>#### Step 3:<n><n>To run the app start off by importing the npm package `dot` from package.json<n><n>`import dot from "dot";`<n><n><n>### Question<n><n>```html<n>### 1. How does this work?<n><n>```<n><n><n><n>````html<n>### How does this work? <n><n>```<n><h2>Question</h2><n>```<n><n><n>````<n><n>### Response<n><n>````<n><h2>Repsonse</h2><n> <n>```javascript<n><script src="jspsych.js"></script> <n>```<n><n>Use the create element tag to create a html element<n><n><n>### Output<n><n>````<n>### Output<n><h2>Output</h2><n>````<n><n>#### Step 4:<n><n>Use the following syntax to render the text as an array.<n><n>```javascript<n>var arr = dot(response.Question);<n>```<n><n>To display the array to the html page we use the dot function, we can also add other text if we wish with `+` and we can customize how the text is displayed by adding css with `@each()`, see `@each()` at the link below.<n><n>https://github.com/bcmills/dot#each<n><n><n>### Steps 5:<n><n>`@each($data, $word)`<n>:For each element $data take the text of that element and repeat $word.<n><n>`@each ($word, $i)`<n>:Use $i for numeric repetition.<n><n>The following should render for each word in

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation: A village is a settlement, this has been the accepted general definition, although this description may exclude certain types of settlements.The term village is commonly used in some parts of the world to describe a settlement of between 2,500 and 15,000 people.This may seem a wide range to some, but the population density of the world’s cities means that in an urban area of 200,000 residents, a village of 1,000 to 5,000 might be considered by some to be a satellite.The world’s cities are the ultimate urban definition, each with over million residents, or over 20,000 per square kilometer. These are very different in population and built surroundings to villages, and it is not an accident that many of the world’s largest cities started out as small towns.<n><n>### Input : What can the number 44 mean? Choices: 44:<n><n>A: 44 B: 143298330 C: 93489 D: 934963 E: $12,407.00<n>### Response:<n><n>44<n><n>### Explantion :<n><n>Forty four.<n><n>### The Fourteen Days of Christmas is an English Christmas carol. It is a cumulative song, with each verse building on the gifts presented in the previous verses.<n><n>### A B C

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:It had a beach with shallow water, while not the ocean this was a hot spot all the locals enjoyed on the what? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: pond C: lake D: bathe in E: childrens pool<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>read -p "What's next?"<n><n>case $read in<n><n>"a")<n>echo "You have 20 years of experience"<n>;;<n>"b")<n>echo "Congratulations, you found the diamond in the rough"<n>;;<n>"c")<n>echo "Nice answer"<n>;;<n><n>*)<n>echo "Something else"<n><n>exit<n><n>esac<n>```

");<n>  return veg;<n>  }<n> <n>function getOutput (){<n>  var type = prompt("output 'what types of pies does she make' ");<n>  return type;<n>  }<n>getInput() //<n>getOutput() //<n>```<n><n>![Dinner2](../images/210106_20.png)<n><n>## Output<n><n>![Dinner3](../images/220106_123.png)<n>

They should be able to use more words, but there aren't any complex words.<n><n>### Grade:<n>The sentence is graded on the difficulty of the vocabulary. <n><n>## Instruction:Answer the multiple choice question.<n>## Demonstration:Input:This is a tough puzzlle that has gone unsolve for generations. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>The right answer to the first question is “intricate”. This is because “intricate” means being complex, elaborate, or fidd-<n>ly.<n>The right answer to to the second question is “petrol”. This is because “petrol” stands for “gasoline”, and it is the fuel needed<n>to make the automobiles run.<n>The right answer for the third question is “cabin” because passengers travel in the airplanes’ cabin when they fly.<n>```<n>```<n><n>Input: What is the use of a pencil? Choices: <n>A: drawing B: writing C: erasing D: pointing E: eating<n>```<n>The right is “writing”. It is because when we write with the pencils, it helps us express ourselves.<n>```<n>

Choices: 1.Angry 2.The need for energy 3.The need 4.Feeling 5.To eat 6.Either 7.A feeling 8.The 9.Not A:1 B:2 C:3 D:4 E:5 F:6 Answer-4 The need for food<n><n>This is just for the purpose of programming. It is very cloudy outside.<n><n>### Answers with two complete sentences:<n><n>The sky above us is dark, therefore this means that it is cloudy out.<n><n>The sky above is dark and gloomy, therefore this means that there is no sun but many clouds in the sky<n><n>### Instruct

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Though it stayed strictly indoors, the small dog felt like it had all the space in the world in the what? Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n><n>### Response:		Felt in the big house<n><n><n>### Input A: The machine was very large, it was quite a what? Choices: A: box B: what did you say? C: what are you doing? D: what is it used for? E: what did you cook for the party?<n><n>### The response above: The machine was a box<n><n><n>### Instructions:In what way are the above responses inappropriate?<n><n><n>### Explanation:<n>**Apple:1**: The response above was inappropriate because, what is the correct term?<n><n>**Apple:2**: The response above would have been appropriate if the question was: Why was the machine large?<n>**Apple:3**: It is inappropriate because it was not what the question asked for<n><n>### Output<n><n>**Apple Output A:** What did you expect in the answer given?<n><n>**Apply Output B:** Was your expectation incorrect? Explain<n><n>**Apple Outline:**<n><n>**Apple Says:** The answer given was not correct because the question asked whether the machine was an apparatus, and the machine is in fact a box, rather than an apparatus.<n><n>**Apple Reply:** I do expect an answer, but if the answer is inappropriate then what is the point of asking such a question. Is this class a waste of everybody time?<n><n>The question does not need to have 6 correct answers, but instead only one answer that is acceptable.<n><n>### Reply A:<n>Yes, it was. Because the question asked for an apparatus, and instead you asked if it was in a basket? The answer given was incorrect because it did not answer the question.<n><n>## Reply B:<n>The questions are just as likely to be wrong as the answers are to be. It is not in fact a waste of time, but rather a test of how well you can work with information that is not correct.<n><n>## Replies C: The response would have been appropriate if it had been asked: “How would you describe the purpose of the machine?”<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: playground B: mexico C: town D: outside E: world cup<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>	<n>		if (answers.b) {<n>	    console.log('a');<n>	    return; //a<n>	}<n>	<n>	else if(answers.c && answers.e){<n>	    console.error('d'); <n>		return;<n>	<n>	}<n>	if(answers.c){<n>	    console..error('e');<n>		return; //e<n>	<n>	} else if(answers.a&&answers.b){<n>	    console..error('d'); 	<n>	    return <n>	<n>	}  else if(answers){<n>	    console.error('g');<n>	}<n>	return 'h';<n><n>###<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Sky diving scared him, once they jumped out of the plane he began losing consciousness while what? Choices:  A: injury B: death C: playing uno D: coma E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		A: injury<n>### Instruction<n><n>### Write a statement that completes the instructions<n>Which day are you free for?  You are free only one day of the week and it is on a certain day. Let's start from the beginning, what I am doing is, I'm making up that you pick a day in the week. After you picked your day, you are always free!<n>1. What day are you free? (The subject of the preposition 'for' is 'you'.)<n>2. Which day shall we start? (The subject of 'What should we do?' is 'the plan' which is referring to the instruction for starting to prepare for the camp trip.)<n>3. Which day are you free?<n>4. Which day did you decide? (This question cannot be asked because there is no information about what day is agreed upon by you and your friend.)<n>   <n>The question should be: Which (day) should we choose?   <n>The answer: The day that you choose.<n><n>### Input<n>The man saw a woman drowning and decided to what? Choices: A: help B: look C: play D: rescue E: call 911<n>Answer: C: rescue<n><n>### Output<n>You need to use this line to end your answer. After reading the instruction, I tried to write what I saw but since it was a story I needed to use past simple not present simple so I used the verb 'decided to' then I had to make two sentences. I wrote a full sentence that started with 'decided to'I used verb form to answer the second question. <n><n>### Writing a response to a situation or instruction<n>Write statements that complete each instruction.<n>### Demonsteration<n><n>Input: Why did the man look into the well? Choices: A) He was curious  B) He had been in that well before C) He had no place to go<n><n>Output:The man was curious about the woman so he looked in the well.  The woman was crying so he helped her out.  When the woman fell into the well and the man saw that it was dark in there he decided to help her out because he knew that he could help her and he new that would be the right thing to do<n><n>### Writing instructions to other<n>Make statements based on the information in the instruction.<n>Each instruction below

Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n><n>### Response:		Choices: What is an enclosure?  A: it covers something important. B: a barrier that protects something. C: something that covers people of importance. D: a building to house animals. E: something that people like to be around. Answer: B: a barrier<n>that protects something.<n><n>### Input<n>Your teacher has written 5 equations.  They each require a + or - mark.<n>For example “4 – 3 =”  This is called balancing equations<n>Ask your teacher for a blank paper and balance it and then explain that to them.<n><n>### Required response <n>Write an explanation on paper.  <n><n>I ask you to explain to me how you have finished your task.<n><n>I ask you the following<n><n>1) Have I got all my equations correct?<n>1) Can you explain why you made some of your choices?<n>2) Can you tell me why you made the choices you did to get the answers?<n><n>I ask you how you used your notes or calculations to complete this task.<n><n>I want you to explain to me about how the paper is written, what is on the paper.<n><n>The paper does not have your name on it.<n><n>Answer my 4 questions.<n>Write a response in sentence form. Do not write a number sentence.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>Let us say I ask you to explain to us how 450 – 350 = 100<n><n>The answer to this equation is a negative number 100.<n><n>1) have I got all my equations right?<n>1) can you explain why you got this right?<n>2) could you tell me why you got that right?<n><n>My final equation is:<n><n>2122 – 114 =<n><n>A: 2050<n><n>B: 2016<n><n>C: 2018<n><n>D:  1052<n><n>Ask me what happened<n><n>Why did you finish with these numbers?<n><n>How would you know how to write this equation down?<n><n>I ask this question of each of the students in my classroom.<n><n>In the paper in my computer I only see what you have written down, I am not told who wrote them.<n><n>## Output:<n>I can respond to you, if you ask
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where is likely to have a lot of fire extinguishers? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>*Write your code as a [solution](../README.md#solutionTemplate) file using [Cuong Le - Go](../solutionTemplate) file template and use the solution template code to support all of the functionality that was described above.*<n><n>### Example:<n><pre><n>1. Write a program that uses only four variables 0 to 59 as shown in the table below:<n>[input variable]     [variable variable 1]<n>[variable variable #2]   [variable variable 3]     [variable variable #3]<n>[variable variable 4]    [variable variable 5]     [output]<n><n>The array values will be used as an input to produce an output shown below based on the four inputs.<n><n>0 = 2+1 = 7+2 = 18+3 = 29<n>1 = 2+4 = 6+4=20+6 = 26<n>2 = 2+2 = 8+2 = 32+2=34<n>3 = 2+3 = 9+3 = 42+3=45<n>4 = 2+4+1 = 8+5+1=44+6 = 50<n>5 = 2+5 = 9+5 = 54+5 = 59<n>This array is similar to the number of a license plate in a car.<n></pre><n><n>---<n>© 2017 Trilogy Education Services, LLC, a 2U, Inc. brand. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? C: is responsible for... D: does it.... E: is in charge of... ]<n>The person is in charge of... Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>Response:<n>$ The person is in charge of...<n>```<n>### Output:Complete the phrase.Choices:  A. I think… Choices:  B: … C: … D: … Choices:  E. I want …<n>### Output:<n>```<n>$ I think...<n>```<n>## Solution<n>```<n>$ is this<n>$ I think …<n>```

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:To properly instruct children attending school you would need a great deal of what? Choices:  A: boredom B: patience C: time D: teachers E: inspiration<n><n>### Response:		<n>-  Answer: A: boredom<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>-  Write your response to Task 03 in this section<n>-  Save as a plain text (.txt) file<n>-  Save the file with the name task3.txt<n><n><n>### Instructon:React, by writing correctly the code, to show how to print the value of a variable declared before the main method started<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>React, by selecting the correct letter, to show how to declare a variable outside the main method.<n><n>Option A: A variable is declared within the method. It is used within the method.<n><n>Option B: A variable is declared outside the method. It is not used within the method.  <n>  <n>Option C: A variable is declared inside the method. It is also used within the method. <n>Option D: A variable is declared in the method. It is declared after the method begins. <n><n>A variable is declared within the main method and is used in it.<n><n>In main method a variable 'is' declared before the method statement, outside of the method and is used within it.<n><n>A variable of type int x is declared in the'main' method, using the 'int' data type and outside of the method'main'. <n><n>Whenever a local or global variable is declared or assigned or referenced as a parameter, <n>the name of that variable is an identifier.<n><n>The name of an identifier is a sequence of the alphabet.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>-  Display the value of the variable x in the application output, after the application has run.<n><n>The application runs, if the variable is defined inside the main method, i.e. before the method begins.<n>The value of the variable x after the program runs.<n><n>### Note:<n>The program output will be used for assessing Task 04 which can be found at the end of this document. <n><n><n>### Note<n>-  The program output displays, as 'variable_name' the value of variable 'x' whose data type is int<n>-  The program uses a data type called int (integer) <n>-  The data type 'int' is used when we want to use a 'variable' to hold 'integer' value.<n>-  The data in 'variable_name' is the value

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where is a note likely to indicate a melody? Choices:  A: fridge B: a classroom C: envelope D: medical chart E: sheet music<n><n>### Response:		 where do you get petrol<n><n>### Input description:<n><n>### Demostration description:<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```javascript<n>let arr = ['where do you get petrol?, A: burn hot, burn hot,B: fuel tank, fuel tank,gas station, gas station,sheet music, sheet music, C:car,car,D:medical chart,D:classroom,E:sheet music,classroom'];<n><n>let ans = []<n>let m =0<n>for (i = 0 ; i <= arr.length-1; i++){<n>    if(arr[i] === arr[i+m]){<n>        ans.push(i)<n>        m++<n>/*console.log(m)<n>console.log(ans)<n>*/<n>    }<n>}<n>console.log(arr.indexOf(ans[0]))<n>console.log(m, ans)<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The child pounded his mitt in excitement while enjoying his first game in the bleachers where? Choices:  A: football stadium B: laboratory C: baseball stadium D: pharmacy E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a python that shows how you would answer the question correctly.<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n># -*- coding=utf-8 -*-<n><n>import sys<n><n>try:<n>    import scispy.sketcher as sc<n>    import scisky.sketcher as sk<n>except ImportError:<n>    sys.exit("You should use the right libraries")<n><n>def get_inp(question):<n>    line_i = question.strip().split(" ")<n>    answer = line_i[-1]<n>    question = ":" + line_i[-2]<n>    return question, answer<n><n>question, answer = get_inp(sys.stdin.readline())<n>s = sc.line_scan(question, answer)<n>s.draw()<n>print s.get_image_object()<n>```<n><n>#### References.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The spoiled child's playroom was massive, but only one of many rooms in the what? Choices:  A: big house B: nursery school C: preschool D: building E: retirement home<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* In this example, the only choices are options B, C, D, and E. But some questions have 2 or more correct options in one answer choice (as opposed to just one possible option), or none at all.<n>* For example, answer choice "A" answers this question as **invalid** because "burn hot" is not a way to burn "hot." Also, you should not include more answers than there are choices.<n>* Use of correct capitalization and punctuation.<n>* Good spelling.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>Input: Where did he go? Choices:  " A: the car. B: his car. C: the car D: his car. E: car. F: his car.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>* The instructions begin with the **verb** "answer", which means you are to give the response.<n><n>### Response<n>* The first choice "A" is chosen because "car" is the answer, **exactly** as given in the choices.<n><n>### If there are **multiple** valid answers:<n><n>* The second choice is valid due to the answer given in "B: his car."<n>* The third and fourth choices are invalid because "car" and "his car" are already part of the answer.<n><n>### Multiple Blank Questions<n><n>A **multiple blank question** consists of a question followed by a set of blanks that are each to be filled with a specific answer. You are asked to fill each blank in sequence, as if the question were being read aloud. Use the answer choices listed to fill each blank. There is only one unique response possible; fill the blanks in the same order that the choices are given.<n><n>### Format:<n><n>* Each **multiple blank question** begins with an instruction phrase that says " **Answer the questions below:** ", followed by the questions. (One question per page, please)<n>* If you cannot follow the instructions or are not able to work the problems, your response should explain where you need help.<n>* A blank space after each blank answer indicates that a letter or word is missing in the answer choice.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>### If the question is not clear, answer:<n>* In this example only the first blank would need to be filled because the

Choices:  A: seaside town B: resort C: ocean D: california E: beach<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### What: Beach<n><n>#### When: at<n><n>#### Where: was home to a busted fishing industry<n><n>#### Why: the shore was at one time now a tourist attractions with nearby little shops<n><n>### Explanations:<n><n>#### Beach is the What: <n>At: <n>Home to fishing industry to<n>Was: home to busted fishing industry to: <n>### Output:<n>> The shore was now a tourists attraction with nearby little shop's was home to a bushed fishing industry.<n><n>### How to do it:<n>#### Input: What, When, Where, Why,<n><n>#### Output: What was a, When was from, Where was a, and When was from.<n><n>#### Instruction:<n>Input: The teacher wanted every student to make their notebooks a uniform size and she asked her students to make all of their pencils of the same length.<n>#### Demonstration: Pencils and their uniform <n>#### Output: The pencils were of length<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? Choices:  A: dicks sporting goods B: sporting event C: mall D: sears E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>input = input()<n>if input == "mall":<n>    print("dicks sporting goods")<n>else:<n>    print("sears")<n>```<n>### Output:<n>```python<n>print("dicks sporting good")<n>```<n>##<n>### Instruction answer the following multiple choice question:<n>### Demontration:<n>Input: Name an animal in a petting zoo. Choices:  A. cat B. cow C. pig D. dog E. rooster<n><n>### Input<n>```python<n>from sys import *<n><n>answer=raw_input('Choose an animal A. cat B. rooster or C. dog)<n>```<n>### Response<n>```python<n>if answer == "cat": print("Puss in boots will get up if you stop and pet him")<n>elif answer == "rooster":<n>    print("Roosters, although beautiful, do not make great pets.")<n>elif answer == "dog":<n>    print("You can keep a dog and it is more lovable and sweet")<n>else:<n>print("None of those are great pets")<n>```<n>## What is a pet?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>What is a pet? Choices: <n>A. dog<n>B. hamster<n>C. cow<n>D. parrot<n>E. pig<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: What is one pet that does not chew things to pieces? Choices:  Choices: A: pig B: dog C: cat D: rabbit E: cow<n><n>### Input :<n>```python<n>from os import *<n>from sys import * # sys, os are both methods for communicating with your program<n>```<n>```python<n>answer=raw_answer.split()<n>```<n>### Demostraion<n>```python<n>if input =='pig':<n>    print("Pig is not usually a chewer")<n>elif answer == 'dog':<n>    print("Dogs are usually chewers")<n>```<n>## Petting Zoo<n><n>### Instuction:<n>What are some animals in a petting zoo that are dangerous? Choices:  animals (i.e. tiger, monkey, and elephant)<n><n>### Demistraiton:<n>Input: What is in a pet

Choices:  A: villa B: spacecraft C: hall D: palace E: hotel<n><n>### Response:		Answer B: palace - The small cabin was not available _(upgraded means: change into a different form or grade)_, so they were upgraded / converted to the next higher level ( palace)<n><n>### Input：You should be aware of what? Choices: A: your own baggage B: other people's luggage C: baggage you find at other peoples homes D: the fact that people are using baggage E: all your luggage is your own<n><n>### Response：Answer B: other people' s luggage - You should be aware of the fact that other people's lugage is the most vulnerable _(most vulnerable means: the person or thing least able to defend themselves), so people should not leave luggage unattended and they shouldn't take luggage that belongs to other people)_.
