Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What business has a tower to transmit signals? Choices:  A: city B: toronto C: radio station D: roger that E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a program that takes the above input and outputs the chosen answer. Do not change or edit anything you did not do for this exercise. Feel free to look at the code on the next page for help.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Copy the following codes and paste them into a new document.<n><n>`def what(self):   return self.chooser()`<n><n><n>#### Code:<n><n>```python<n>def what(self):<n>  return self.chooser()<n>```<n><n>```python<n>import random <n><n>class What_201821(object):<n>  def __init__(self):<n>    self.chooser = random.randrange(0,6)<n>    self.choices = ['A','B','C','D','E','F']<n><n>  def how_is_it(self,self.chooser):<n>    return self.chooser<n>  def what (self):<n>    return self<n>```<n>If possible, make sure that your answer passes the following test.<n><n><n>## Test Cases:<n><n>### Test case 1<n>```python<n>class What_22(object):<n>  class What_(self):<n>    def __init__(self,self = 'A'):<n>      self.choices = 'A','B','C'<n>    def what_(self):<n>      return self.choices<n>    <n><n>    def what_as_function(self):<n>      return 'b'<n><n><n>def test1():<n>  what_1 = What_22().What_22()<n>  print what_1.what_as_function()<n>```<n>### Test case2<n>```python<n>class what(object):<n>  what = None<n><n>  def __init(self):<n>    random.seed<n>    rn = random.choice<n>    self.choicer_list = ["random"]<n><n><n>  def how(self,self.get_chooser_list):<n>    return self[self.choicer_get_list]<n><n><n><n>class how_as_function(object):<n>  print 'How'<n>  def how_(self,self):<n>  rn = random.chooser<n><n>class test_23(object):<n>  if how_choices = True:<n>    print how_choices<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Why do people engage in chatting with friends in class? Choices:  A: necessity B: answers C: inspiration D: love E: fun<n><n>### Response:		Why do people converse with friends in class?<n><n>```python<n>if answer == "A":<n>    print("necessity")<n>elif answer == "B":<n>    print("answers")<n>elif answer =="C":<n>    print("inspiration")<n>elif answer = "D":<n>    print("love")<n>else <n>    print("fun")<n>```<n><n>### Input <n><n>A: Where do you get fuel from? Choices:  B: car C: fuel D: garage E: engine fuel<n><n>Answer: E: garage<n><n>Why do you buy a fuel? Choices:<n><n>A: drive B: gas C: fuel D: to buy B: fuel<n><n>Answer: D: to buy<n>```<n>if answer == B:<n>    print("gas")<n>elif answer == C:<n>    print("fuel")<n>elif answer == D:<n>    print("to buy")<n>else:<n>    print("garage")<n>```<n><n>Input: Why don't people like wasting money? Choices: <n>A: because they are too rich<n>B: they are not rich<n>C: why would I be rich<n>D: I have no idea<n>Answer: C: why would I be too rich<n>```<n>if answer_question == A:<n>    print("people wouldn't worry about wasting money because they are too rich")<n>elif answer_question == B:<n>    a=raw_input("Do you answer the question right?")#get input<n>    if a == "Yes" :<n>        print("they can still waste money")<n>else:<n>        print("they are not rich")<n>```<n><n>*Important* This solution is not elegant. <n>As we are writing code at an intermediate level in this case I am only showing one way to solve a problem that can be improved using more elegant solutions that I will teach you later.<n><n>### Input<n>The following items are used to clean the office. Choices:<n><n>1 A:  The mop 1 B: The duster 2 C: the tray 3 D: The broom 4 E: the mop <n><n>Answer: E<n>```<n>question = input("What tools are used for cleaning the office? : ") #get what tools I use<n><n>if question == "1":<n>    print

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:They don't get grades or sit at desks, but crowds of fish do what? Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n><n>### Response:		Answer all questions<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: He used the calculator to do some quick fractions. Choices: A: divide B: subtract C: add D: multiply E: divide<n>Answer: D: multiply<n><n>Input: I am quite an expert in photography. Choices: A B C D E<n><n>Answer: B: expert<n><n><n>### Review<n>1. If the word is in uppercase you should have a capital letter in your response.<n>2. If the word is lowercase then you should have a lower case.<n><n>### Challenge<n>1. What are the properties of a valid machine input? Which ones are examples of machine input and which ones are false?<n>2. What are the properties that describe the question type? Which ones describe a challenge?<n><n>#### Machine Input<n>The machine is looking for questions it can understand and respond to.<n><n><n>#### Question Type<n>It has a few properties that define the type of question that needs answering.<n><n><n><n>### Test: <n>1. What is a valid machine input? What if it is an invalid input?<n>2. You're driving down the highway listening to the radio and come across a question, but you're driving and you have other things to pay attention to the car, does your response have to be 100% correct on the first try?<n>3. What is a good practice to develop responses?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some airplanes that are not being used? Choices:  A: war B: aircraft carrier C: sky D: graveyard E: crash<n><n>### Response:		B: aircraft carrier and D: crash<n><n>## :point_right: Additional Information<n><n>### Hint:<n>To find the answer for the inputs, the following techniques can be use:<n>- Check for synonyms.<n>An example of a synonym is, airplanes is a synonym for aircraft. Therefore, the input could be something like, "Where could you find some jets that are not being used?"<n>- Capitalising<n>An example of capitalising the correct phrase to represent the input would be, "Where in the sky can you find some old planes?" <n>- Plurial<n>An example of pluralising the input to correct its grammaticality would be, "Where can you find some plummeted ships?" <n>

The boss E. your teacher<n><n>### Response - Choose one of the choices from the list and write on one line, the person in the sentence.<n>C. John<n>D. Mr. Smith, Jr<n><n>Answer: D: Mr. Smith,Jr<n>E. The boss<n><n>Input:I was able to read the sign at the corner? Choices: A : I could B: I was C: He saw D: That she saw E: I see<n><n>Input: The dog sits, does the dog sit? She accepted her fate like the man who ate the apple in the Garden of Eden.<n><n>### Response<n><n>

Choices:  A: alive B: health C: fun D: playing dead E: black<n><n>### Response:		Answer: Choices: A: alive<n><n>### Task:<n>Write a python program that simulates the functionality of a virtual robot which simulates the movements of the buttons on a keyboard.<n>For this project, you will design and implement an interactive program wherein the program can be run from user to user input. The program should demonstrate your ability to create an interactive program, use the Python input() and output() methods and understand the standard functions, statements, and operators in Python.<n><n>### Assumptions:The virtual robot knows the following commands and their meanings and is able to perform the actions.<n><n>### Commands:<n>- move up or down one on the keyboard<n>- take one<n>- put one<n>- clear any keys inputted<n>- reset<n>    You may assume that the user doesn't move any keys for the 1 minute before you begin the project.<n>    The user enters the command line prompts (that is, the text inside the quotes) through the keyboard, either by entering the text and pressing "enter" to execute it, or by using the standard keyboard commands for tabbing or pressing arrow keys to move the cursor into the correct position, and then entering each character.<n>    You may assume the user enters everything in the quotations unless the user says to clear the keys, in wich case the user will type "clear".<n><n>The following table outlines the actions the command, and which key they match:<n><n>#### Commands and Key Associations:<n>- Clear any keys: The user inputs "clear"<n>- Put One: If the user entered a number, the robot puts it on the screen<n>- Put blank: If the user didn't enter a number, the robot simply put "blank"<n>- Take One: The user types in a number and the robot takes that number<n>- Move Up/Down: The user types a number and the robot moves up or down that number<n>- Key is clear: The user inputs "K is clear"<n>- Move to last: The user inputs "mmove to last"<n>- Reset: The user inputs "reset"<n><n>The program should display the user's instructions (as entered in the input commands) on the screen and respond with the next step for the program.<n>For example, if the user types "move up 1", the program must respond by moving the value of "1" and then display (or
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:How does getting paid feel? Choices:  A: income tax B: satisfaction C: sorrow D: ocean E: bill collectors to happy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* How do you know that you received an electric shock?<n>  Whenever you are connected to an electric source, you will feel a shock.<n>* Do you know what was the last movie you watched?<n>  **Yes**, it was the blockbuster **Fantastic Beastro 2**.<n>  **No**, I didn't watch any movie because they were busy.<n>* What do you think of the new 2018 model of Range Rover?<n>  I think its looks stylish with the chrome body kit.<n>* How was your trip?<n>  My trip was amazing. The airplane flew smooth. I had a chance to rest in the first-class section. There was a very good selection for food and the seats were comfortable.<n>* What do the police want us to stop doing?<n>  They wanted us to stop stealing, fighting, cheating, destroying property and not obey laws. They asked us to obey traffic rules.<n>* Do you think there are less chickens left?<n>  Yes, there are less chicken now.<n>  No, there are the same number of chickens.<n>  Not sure.<n><n>### The Task<n><n>What will your robot do?<n><n>### Driving Directions<n><n>Drive 50 feet straight forward.<n><n>Turn 90 degrees right.<n><n>Drive 100 feet straight forward. <n><n>Drive 80 feet at angle of 90 degrees right to the left. <n><n>Drip 4 inches forward. <n><n>Turn 180 degrees right. <n> <n> Drip 5 inches backward.<n><n>Turn 175 degrees left. <n><n>Turn until on the edge of the road. <n><n>Driving Directions:  (Optional)<n><n>Drive for 2 meters forward. <n><n>Keep straight for about 2 meters until you're about 0.5 meters from the curb.<n><n>Drive a right angle turn until you are on a curb.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: 	<n><n>### Delivery<n><n>Drivelogs:  (Optional)  <n><n>Delivery Description<n>The delivery can be completed successfully. (Yes)<n><n>I have no clue what the thing is. (Yes)<n>

Where do you get petroil from? the accident happened behind the car wash, it was blocking the road.The woman asked the police to move the accident and take the driver to the police station, they did just that.<n><n>There was a lady in a petrol station, she cut her finger while chopping a onion.The lady, while she was cutting the onion with the knife, she cut her finger and there was petrol.<n>A car ran into a truck that had crashed from a car accident. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. This was bad.  He would be unable to hold his tools if he injured what? Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```text<n>The input is:<n>He would be unable to hold (his) tools if he injured his fists.<n>Let us add the prepositional phrase [his fists] to the answer to the original question.<n>Let us rewrite the question like this and the result in the answer is as given below:<n>How can John injure his fists?<n>Where can he injure his fists if he injures his fists?<n>Let us rewrite the answer:<n>He (John) would be unable to hold [his] tools if he injured his (left and/or right) fists.<n>John can injure his fists by knocking on the wall with his fists like he did earlier.<n>But, he can't do his work. Because he injured his fists and then he can't hold tools.<n>```

Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>###<n><n>```python<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>##<n><n>###<n>```<n>**Hint:**<n><n>Use the `word=` key to search for a word inside the input string.<n><n>```python<n>import numpy<n><n>word="It was a nice"<n><n><n>def word(input_string):<n><n>    if(input_string.count(word)==1):<n>        index = input_string.index(word)<n>        return index<n><n>    #else:<n>    return -1<n><n>if __name__ == "__main__":<n>    print(word("It was a nice"))<n>```<n>

What type of container do you think it was? Choices: 	 A: Mug B: Tea kettle C: Bottle D: jug E: bucket<n>Output: Mug<n><n>Output: You forgot the container.<n><n>### Input. Please leave the container after you are done. How many times did he/she have to tell the user to leave the container?<n><n>### Response. The person asked the user how many times they had been told leave the container and was told once.<n>``` ruby<n><n>while (!done) do<n>	puts "Please leave an empty container for coffee, it looks like<n>you made a lot."<n><n><n>	puts "What type of container do you<n>think it was?"<n><n><n>	answer = getstr.downcase<n>	<n>	if (answer in ['mug', 'cup', 'pot', 'jar', 'jug'])<n>		sleep 1<n>	else<n>		puts "The container must be empty after you're done"<n>	end<n>end<n>```<n>### Instruction: What would be a good program for someone to write who wanted to make sure they did not leave their house without their wallet when they left, and they were afraid they might forget their wallet? If so, did you put in your coat?"<n> 			coat = gets.chomp()<n> 			if (coat.downcase == 'no')<n>	  <n> 				print "Oh, so you left the coat behind, as well?"<n> 		  <n> 	 			print 'Please don’t forget your wallet

Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The person was looking up airline and hotel prices, what was he looking to do? Choices:  A: control computer B: separate things C: go on vacation D: cross street E: go out<n><n>### Response:		The person was looking to go on vacation. Answer: E: go out.<n>### Answer Code:<n>- [X] Multiple Selection<n><n>### Feedback:<n>This question tested ________ skills.<n><n>##### Hint:<n>Ask yourself what skills you used to complete the task. It is important to check that these are the right skills.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Think how you would complete the task on your computer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The woman picked from an apple tree while surrounded by other trees, where was she? Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n>- The woman picked from an apple what? Choices: A: tree B: farmer's stall C: store D: store window<n>- Where was she? Choices :  A: woods B: illinois C: farmer's shop D: gas station<n>Answer : A: tree B: woods C: farmer'a shop D: farmer's marker<n><n><n>### Input : What did the man put onto the potato? Choices :  B: potato  A: salt  C: vegetables  D: water  E: meat<n>- What did the man put on the potato?  Choices: A: vegetables B: salt C: meat D: water<n><n>### Response :<n><n>```javascript<n>let choices = [A,B,C,D,E];<n>let answer = parseInt(prompt("What did the man put on  the potato?"));<n>const indexOfSelectedChoice = choices.findIndex(i => i === answer);<n>while (indexOfSelectedChoice!== -1) {<n>  indexOfSelectedChoice == "water"? answer = 4 : indexOfSelectedChoice = "water";<n>}<n>const choice = A.toUpperCase();<n>prompt(choice);<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The person is laying on the beach, why would he do that? Choices:  A: sun himself B: thank god C: race against time D: express love E: to think about things.<n><n>### Response:		The person might be laying on the beach to express his love. You must choose a different choice from the choices (A-E ) that contains an answer to the question.<n><n>## Examples of correctly formatted answers<n><n>Please write a response that appropriately replies to the person with a task.<n><n>### Sample #1<n><n>Because you are answering another person's question, you must be sure to use the person's name (if given) and use the appropriate form of "you".<n><n>If you're a tutor and replying to a student, use the first person ("I") when you start your response. You can switch to second person ("you") when you state the task.<n><n>You should also write a sentence or two of explanation that describes how your response addresses the topic question.<n><n>For example:<n><n>```<n>Tutor: What is the capital of the country you live in?<n><n>Student: France<n><n>Tutor: That's correct because you are in France, but there are many countries with the name France.<n><n>Tutor: The capital of France is called Paris.<n><n>Tutor (switching to second person): What is the capital of France?<n><n>Student: Oh, sorry my bad, I meant Canada.<n>Tutor: That is correct your answer is Canada<n>```<n><n>Please note that the above example is using a bit of the student's choice for a conversation starter with an attempt to guide the conversation back on the topic question. This is not allowed on Task-Based Writing Assignments.<n><n>### Example #2<n><n>This example features a topic question that is in the incorrect tense and a completely unnecessary conversation starter.<n><n>```<n>Student: Could you tell me where can I find [insert random place].<n><n>Tutor: I do not know! It would be useless.<n>```<n><n>### Example#3<n><n>In this type of question-answer exchange, there is no useful information regarding the topic question. In fact, they are using random words to generate their own conversation.<n><n>```<n>Teacher: Do you like the teacher?<n><n>Student: Yes, but she is too serious. She needs to chill a bit.<n>```<n><n>Study Buddies does not permit conversation starters or meaningless answers that deviate from the original request.<n><n>## Questions and Answers
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What does someone want when having fun with their friends and trying to fit in? Choices:  A: being understood B: beer C: playing around D: hug E: visiting friends<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>[The machine was quite an <n>`APPARATUS`: The machine was quite an apparatus]<n><n>[Where do you get petrol <n>`GAS`: Where do you get petroleum?]<n><n>[What does someone want when <n>`FUN`: What does someone want when playing?]<n><n>[My brother was playing <n>`WITH`: At my brother was playing with.]<n><n>### Hint:<n>An algorithm can solve this task.<n>Try this.<n><n>1. Write a message<n>2. Input the message<n>3. Try all possibilities<n><n>

Choices:  A : box  B : apparatus  C : appliance  D : implement  E : wash dishes<n><n>### Response : A box is a container, not an apparatus. An apparatus is a large, complicated machine. The train meets that definition.<n><n>### It's 9 o'clock. Choices: 1 A: O'Clock 2 B: Eight O 3 C: nine 4 D: O'twelve 5 E: O'thirty<n><n>### Response A: O'clock is too obvious, so obviously wrong. D: O'clock is obviously correct.<n><n>### The first thing we did was to put all of it in the carrier. Choice A: Put: this makes no sense at all, since items aren't put within the carrier by default, they are put into the baggage carrier of a plane.<n><n>### Transport the carrier into the back seat of the car. Choices:  Scooby: The front seat is back and therefore can be called the back seat.  Scooby: Since the carrier is already in the back seat, you now put the bag and baggage in it, therefore, "Put the baggage in the carrier, then set the carrier into the front seat."<n><n>### What about the other items? Choices:  S: The front seat of the car is called the back seat. The other seats are called the front seats.  T: It matters about the where it goes.<n>

The question is: Wherein a town do you put your shed? One of the choices is farm yard, so you would choose C as your response, which is farm yard.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>Farm yard is the answer.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: Wherein a town where you put your shed?<n><n>### Output<n><n>Answer: Farm yard in a town is the correct term.<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>We have just answered the multiple choice question. We are asking where we put our shed in a town. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: shelf B: desktop C: cabinet D: kitchen E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Question 1. What do we put that in?<n><n>#### Question 2. Where do I put it down?<n><n>```jsx<n>class Demo extends React.Component {<n>    constructor(props) {<n>        super(props);<n>        this.state = {};<n>    }<n><n>    performTheTask = () => {<n>        this.setState({question: true});<n>    }<n>}<n><n>class App extends React.Component { <n><n>    render = () => {<n>         return (<n>            <div><n>              <Button onClick={this.performTheTask} label="Submit">Submit</Button><n>              <div>{this.state.question}</div><n>            </div><n>         );<n>    }<n>} <n><n>ReactDOM.render(<n>    <App /><n>   , document.querySelector('#root'));<n><n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:John is a human who is in a wheelchair due to an accident.  Where would he go to get to the third floor of his apartment building? Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following short-answer question.<n><n>Input:Write a three-sentence paragraph in which you explain the difference between the functions of the preoperational and concrete operational stages of development that Jean Piaget wrote about. <n><n>### Response<n>Learners at the preoperational stage of development are unable to understand the causality of concrete events around them, whereas the operational stage is able to understand this causality and the operations that occur. For instance, the pre-operational is unable to differentiate one object for another, for example, between bread and a toy car, and cannot even distinguish the concept of bread from one of a toy bus, though these things are in the same setting and may share some features. However, the operational stage is capable of performing mental operations, such as differentiating between symbols of various objects represented on paper, and being able to calculate a sum.<n><n>

Choice: A: money B: money B: respect C: money C: job security D: money D: success<n><n>######<n><n>![Alt text 2](https://i.imgur.com/K42Q4kT.png)<n><n>######<n>[The task](https://github.com/KoalaJungle/KoalaJuju/blob/dev/app/app/views/task/00002_reading.coffee#L20 "The task")<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>###### 4 / 5<n>* [BBC News](http://www.bbc.com/news)<n>* [The Guardian](http://www.theguardian.com/world)<n>* [CNET](http://www.cnet.com/news/mystery-deepens-in-san-francisco-over-deadly-fire/)<n>* [New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/news)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where do fish spend the majority of their time? Choices:  A: body of water B: lake superior C: underwater D: toilet E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>An apparatus is:<n><n>A thing in general that someone can understand as being useful or functional.<n><n>A machine that is used for a particular purpose.<n><n>an apparatus.<n><n>An object or machine used for a particular purpose, especially an electronic one used for a particular type of computing or communication.<n><n>### Feedback<n>1. Select the correct response.<n>   1. It is not an object or machine used for some specified function or purpose (machine)<n>   2. It is an object or machine as part of a bigger apparatus<n>   3. It is an object used for a particular function<n>   4. It is a type of thing with a specific function<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>- One does not understand the word. So ask to clarify.<n><n>- A type of object is a **machine**. It can not be used to fulfill a purpose.<n><n>- The word could be replaced.<n>- The word could not be replaced.<n><n>### Resources:<n><n>[English grammar](https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/grammar#english)<n><n>https://quizlet.com/304029839/ap-english-language-and-composition-1-review-flash-cards/

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:If electrical equipment won't power on, what connection should be checked? Choices:  A: company B: telephone netwok C: airport D: wires E: freeway<n><n>### Response:		<n>Electrical problems with an item can often be resolved by changing the appliance's plug. In many cases, the connection of a new plug may solve the problem. An electrician can often determine if plug connections themselves are defective and if so, they can replace the plugs. If the problem is not resolved after replacements, the items wiring should be inspected.<n><n>### Input:- The gasoline company delivered propellent in the form of an? Choices:  Choices:  A. air B. gas C. fuel D. oil E. liquid <n><n>### Response:- A. [air](https://quizlet.com/50363651/chapter-11-flash-cards/)<n><n>### Input<n>"I don't know where it went, but I'm sure it's gone." What does this statement mean? Choices: A: Gone because someone stole it B: Gone because I lost it C: Gone because I put it where I couldn't find it D: Gone because I'm confused.<n><n>### Response<n>According to the statement "I don't know [where it went], but I'm sure [it has gone](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/gone)" <n><n>"gone" is an adjectival phrase modifying the noun _[it](https://dictionary.youglish.com/?i=-it)-_ this means that "gone" is describing the thing, and this indicates its missing property, which is the ability to be found<n><n>### Input.<n>We used the gasoline company's tube to refill water.Choices:  Choice: A. gas B. propellant C. liquid D. air <n><n>### Direction<n>The meaning is correct, but the grammar, phrasing, and word choice need improvement.<n><n>### Output<n>* I filled the propellant tank with an outside gasoline tube.<n>* I filled an outside gasoline tank with fuel.<n>* I filled the gasoline tank with propane gas.<n>* I filled my car with fuel by a gasoline tube. <n><n>### Input : I took my family out to eat at the restaurant we always go in. Choices: <n><n>### Dem
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where above your kitchen sink could you store canned food? Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		 C: grocery<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>*A machine is an object that can be switched on to perform some function.*<n>A. Box<n>B. Apparatus<n>C. Appliance<n>D. Wash dishes<n>E. Implement<n><n>**A** is incorrect because a box is a box.*<n>**B** is incorrect because an apparatus is only related to machines.*<n>**C** is incorrect because an appliance is only related to machines in the kitchens.*<n>**D** is incorrect because washing dishes does not have anything in common with machine.*<n>**E** is incorrect because machines are for use.*<n><n>A machine is an object made to work.*<n>A. Implement<n>B. Apparatus <n>C. Appliance <n>D.Box<n>E.Cupboard<n><n>*Where above your kitchen sink  could you store canned goods? Choices: <n>*A: cupboard<n>*B: oven<n>*C: grocery store<n>*D: pantry<n>*E: cellar. <n>*A.* is incorrect because you can not store canned food in a cupboard <n>*B.* is incorrect because you could not store canned food below the stove.*<n>*C.* is correct because grocery stores have many canned goods.*<n>*D.* is incorrect because a pantry is a cupboard for storing food.*<n><n>*Response:  C: groceries.*<n><n>### Comments:<n><n>### Reference<n><n>[1]https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/general-english-course-for-adults/grammar/practical-english-grammar-1865079265?#fndtn-information-tab-tocgridtab-chapter-1<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What is KFC who serves chicken? Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n><n>### Response:		I’d like one KFC who serves chickens please.<n><n>### Output: What would you like to have?<n><n>### Explanations:<n>We would eat dinner.<n><n>Input: What will you serve for dinner? Choices:  i: dinner ii: lunch iii: tea iv: beverages v: breakfast x: a question.<n><n><n><n>##### Solution:<n>```<n>import java.util.*;<n><n>class Solution_7_02<n>{<n>    public static void main(String[] args)<n>    {<n>        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);<n>            <n><n>        while (true)<n>        {<n>            String question = in.nextLine();<n>            if (!question.matches("^[A-Z ]+$"))<n>            {<n>                <n>                System.out.println("Please enter a question only in uppercase letters.");<n>                System.exit(0);<n>            }<n>            List answer_list = read();<n>            String answer = in.nextLine().toLowerCase();<n><n>            System.out.println(process(question, answer_list, answer));<n><n>            System.in.read();<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>    private static String process(String question, List answer_list, String answer) {<n>        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();<n>        for (int i=0; i<answer.length(); i++) <n>        {<n>            if (i==0) <n>            {<n>                sb.append(answer.charAt(i)+' ');<n>            } <n>            else <n>            {<n> <n>                sb.append(" "+answer.charAt(0)+' ');<n>          <n>            }<n>            if (answer.charAt(answer.length()-1)-1 == answer.charAt(i))<n>            {<n>                i++;<n>                sb.append("\n(e.g) ");<n>            }<n>            sb.append(answer_list.get(answer.charAt((answer.length()-5)>> 1))+'\n');<n>        }<n>     <n>        System.out.println("\n");<n>        StringBuilder string = new StringBuilder();<n><n>        for (String ans : answer_list)<n>        {<n>            <n>            System.out.print(i+1);<n><n>        }<n><n>

I know the difference between funny and humurous. And I know I can use those words to refer to the same feeling of enjoyment (humurous) or ammusement (humurous). I also know that "funnier" and "humourous" are not accepted as synonyms. I'm certain that "funniest" and "humourless" are not acceptable synonyms. You did this by using the appropriate form of the word apparatus. To answer this question you don't need to know the exact form of the word apparathus.  <n>In the 2nd sentence, you were requested answer this question using the appropriate form of words mentioned above.<n><n>In the 3rd sentence, again you were requested to describe the appropriate form of the verb help. Then you were requested to answer this question using the form of words mentioned above and finally, answer this question using the noun government which you were requested to describe by using the form of the relevant (appropriate) form of the word government.<n><n>![Sample_result](https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/e/2PACX-1vRl6xQ8YpRDXw5dG6_FQyWZC41zP84z6b99Y0JbJ0D_J9qYxKKO41q1HqwWa317YvY6xCY-5iOOZQ/pub?w=598&h=173&e=0)<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What is someone likely to feel after receiving a gift that is not common? Choices:  A: special B: personal C: offended D: unique E: rare<n><n>### Response:		<n>What you write as the response will depend on which task that is called into play. For each multiple choice question, write the answer as a number (e.g. _9_ or _5_), or a statement (e.g. "C: _Burn hot_"). To the questions where responses are written words or short phrases, write the response as a regular sentence.<n><n>**Note: the following response structure is not necessary, but it can be used to help structure responses in an easy-to-follow fashion that helps the reader:**<n><n>__Question:__ <n>#### Answer: __Option_1__<n><n>___Or_____<n><n>__Question:_<n>#### Answer: __option_2__<n><n>### Input<n>What is the question's "question"?<n>What is your answer to the question? Include the question's answer, so that I know you answered it correctly, and you know how to correctly answer it.<n><n><n>### Output Description<n><n>**Input:** <n>#### "Question.<n>#### <n><n>Your answer:<n>####<n><n>### Code Implementation<n>(Write your code here)<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: builders B: driver C: architect D: fall down E: tradesmen<n><n>### Response:		What do builder do? Choices:  Building houses Building cars Building trees Building the moon<n><n>### Challenge:<n>What does the word "architect" mean? Choices: architectures houses, architecture skyscrapers, architectures cars, architectures buildings.<n><n>### Solution:<n>- Choice A: answer: architecture houses, answer: architect a house, architects houses.<n>- Choice B: answer: architects skyscrapers Choice C: answer: architect cars. Choice D: answer: architecture buildings.<n><n>#### References<n>1. https://www.educationworld.com/a_teachers/admin/admin236.shtml<n>2. https://www.wikihow.com/Teach-Reading-Comprehension<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The man on the street corner was showing off a wristwatch, he was trying to what it for drug money? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: case C: hock D: watch store E: pawn<n><n>### Response:		<n>When typing the response, think about the following.<n><n>* What was described in step 1.<n>* What are the options/choices in the example.<n>* Which option did the writer choose?<n>* Which option would best complete the sentence?<n>* What word would be best in that position.<n><n>### Expected Response:<n>When typing up the response choose one of the answers from the example. The response should include:<n><n>* A statement that gives the correct response; the writer selected the correct answer.<n>* Why did they selected the correct answer; explain your reasoning.<n>* Be as specific as possible.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What kind of radio does someone use to reach base? Choices:  A: vessel B: box C: transistor D: submarine E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		Choice D is the best answer. Answers: A: box<n><n>#### Answer: D is the best answer, an object submarine is also called a box, but it is not a box to which we refer.<n><n>#### Answer: C is the best answer, the answer to the question of your radio is transistor, it is not an apparatus.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where would you find fungus growing on something made from milk? Choices:  A: eyes B: biology laboratory C: shower stall D: old cheese E: decaying matter<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input is 1st character and number then word or phrase and then number<n>### The word "where" is missing from the sentence<n>### The sentence is incomplete<n>Incomplete answer: A: where butter<n>### The sentence has two subject verb pairs- where(verb)is, where(verb)you(subject)<n>### The subject is missing from the last part of the sentence<n>Missing subject: you get fungus<n><n>### Instructor's Response:<n>A: where butter is<n><n>### Demorstration:<n>Input sentence  You get fungus growing on something in the kitchen. Choices: A: burn hot B. fuel tank C: burn in hot D: car E gas station Input sentence The machine was very intricite, it was a very interesting.
